description:
I have submitted this once already but noone from the team gave me an answer. I want to subsubscribe from the mailing list, hitting the “Save settings” once selecteing “No mail” doesn’t have an affect.

Can I please get some assistance on this.

submitter_user.about:
I’m Tristan B. Kildaire (or deavmi on the Internet) and I’m a computer programmer. I love tinkering around with all the bits of software that my computer runs but typically more on the low-level sides of things. I’m really interested in how operating systems work as a whole and their components such as kernels, networking stacks, linking-loaders, IPC, paging, virtual memory, file-systems and the list goes on. There’s so much to learn from understanding these complex systems and each aspect of them never leaves me bored!

You could call me a language enthusiast, from the design to the implementation. I always want to know how things work and I’ve even spent time reading the source code for some language runtimes to get a better understanding. If I am feeling creative then I try write my own or write something in Forth! I love building networks too - I have an interest in setting up inter-networks with routing protocols, assigning numbers and setting up tunnels in order to build a huge network that I can play around on. When I’m not using other peoples' protocols I am busy writing my own to see what I can cobble out to itch my scratch on trying interesting concepts out.

I like a good glass of red wine and cheese. I have an avid enjoyment for music from the 70s and the 80s and have rather interesting political views (nothing to be alarmed of) but most importantly I like to help others learn and put a smile on their face.

title: git-cliff 1.3.0 is released - a highly customizable changelog generator
2023-08-30 Outage Midmortem
description:
At 18:45 Chicago time I took prod down for what was supposed to be a straightforward Ubuntu update from 20.04 LTS to 22.04 LTS. Lobsters runs on three VPSs, named db01 (runs mariadb), web01 (runs nginx, puma, mail, everything else), and mockturtle (IRC bot). I wrote a checklist and completed a full database backup as the first step. The upgrade for db01 went fine. (I never got to mockturtle.)

The upgrade for web01 did not go fine. It crashed, but not quite to terminal (do-release-upgrade does something clever with screen). The upgrade process was still running in the background, though the screen session was gone so I couldn’t reattach and resume. Some eyeballing with lsof and ps showed it wasn’t doing anything, but it wasn’t possible to kill and some other diagnostic commands segfaulted. While irritating, all the site data is on db01 (and in the backup I just took) so I executed an industry best-practice contingency.

The web01 VPS did not come back up. I spent ~75 minutes locked out of the DigitalOcean web dashboard because (real shining moment here) two years ago I’d set the email to a unique address independent of my usual hosting as one more ATO precaution and forgot to update it in my password manager. (Yes, it has 2FA as well, with recovery codes stored securely offline.) Support was unresponsive, and my attempts to backchannel to employees did not get a response. While stress casually shed my remaining gray hairs, I read through every email I’d ever gotten from DO in search of more contacts and noticed an email confirming the email change. I was immediately able to log in to the dashboard.

From the dashboard’s recovery console I could only see a kernel panic, which persisted when rebooting. It looks like hardware failure or bad filesystem corruption, so I set about rebuilding the vps. Unfortunately our ansible setup didn’t work out of the box. Mostly it was missing certbot setup, but there were many smaller tweaks for a cold start.

Double unfortunately, DigitalOcean gave the box an IP that’s blacklisted for sending spam. @strugee got us delisted from SpamHaus, but there are more. So don’t expect to get email for the moment.

Core site functionality is working, but probably less common features are broken. The replying_comments view is running at ~6000ms instead of its usual brisk (cough) ~200-600ms, so page loads are slow while logged in. Please report further issues on GitHub. I’m going to go to bed, because I’m starting to make dumb mistakes from fatigue and it’d be a shame to immediately break production after so much hassle getting it running again. I’ll answer comments and bug reports with comments or an edit to this story after I’ve gotten some sleep.

Sorry for the inconvenience and take care,

  • Peter
description_plain:
At 18:45 Chicago time I took prod down for what was supposed to be a straightforward Ubuntu update from 20.04 LTS to 22.04 LTS.
Lobsters runs on three VPSs, named db01 (runs mariadb), web01 (runs nginx, puma, mail, everything else), and mockturtle ([IRC](https://lobste.rs/chat) [bot](https://github.com/lobsters/mockturtle/)).
I wrote a checklist and completed a full database backup as the first step.
The upgrade for db01 went fine.
(I never got to mockturtle.)

The upgrade for web01 did not go fine.
It crashed, but not quite to terminal (`do-release-upgrade` does something clever with `screen`).
The upgrade process was still running in the background, though the screen session was gone so I couldn't reattach and resume.
Some eyeballing with `lsof` and `ps` showed it wasn't doing anything, but it wasn't possible to kill and some other diagnostic commands segfaulted.
While irritating, all the site data is on db01 (and in the backup I just took) so I executed an [industry best-practice contingency](https://offandonagain.org).

The web01 VPS did not come back up.
I spent ~75 minutes locked out of the DigitalOcean web dashboard because (real shining moment here) two years ago I'd set the email to a unique address independent of my usual hosting as one more [ATO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credit_card_fraud#Account_takeover) precaution and forgot to update it in my password manager.
(Yes, it has 2FA as well, with recovery codes stored securely offline.)
Support was unresponsive, and my attempts to backchannel to employees did not get a response.
While stress casually shed my remaining gray hairs, I read through every email I'd ever gotten from DO in search of more contacts and noticed an email confirming the email change.
I was immediately able to log in to the dashboard.

From the dashboard's recovery console I could only see a kernel panic, which persisted when rebooting.
It looks like hardware failure or bad filesystem corruption, so I set about rebuilding the vps.
Unfortunately our ansible setup didn't work out of the box.
Mostly it was missing certbot setup, but there were [many smaller tweaks for a cold start](https://github.com/lobsters/lobsters-ansible/compare/c29c5f9...d04283b).

Double unfortunately, DigitalOcean gave the box an IP that's blacklisted for sending spam.
@strugee got us delisted from SpamHaus, but there are more.
So don't expect to get email for the moment.

Core site functionality is working, but probably less common features are broken.
The `replying_comments` view is running at ~6000ms instead of its usual brisk (cough) ~200-600ms, so page loads are slow while logged in.
Please [report further issues on GitHub](https://github.com/lobsters/lobsters).
I'm going to go to bed, because I'm starting to make dumb mistakes from fatigue and it'd be a shame to immediately break production after so much hassle getting it running again.
I'll answer comments and bug reports with comments or an edit to this story after I've gotten some sleep.

Sorry for the inconvenience and take care,

- Peter

submitter_user.about: Hi, I'm [Peter Bhat Harkins](https://malaprop.org), a programmer and entrepreneur from Chicago. From June 2014 to winter of 2015 I typically posted a dozen stories per day to [help](https://lobste.rs/s/9pm09z/what_is_on_topic_what_is_not/comments/nie0yn#c_nie0yn) the site reach a critical mass of regular visitors. In October 2017 I became the site administrator after the site creator @jcs stepped down. * Please don’t message me for an invitation if we're complete strangers; check the user list for someone you know or ask [in chat](https://lobste.rs/chat). * Submit a [`meta`](https://lobste.rs/t/meta) post for feature requests (including new tags) to let the community discuss. Bug reports and "is this a bug?" should go to [the issue tracker](https://github.com/lobsters/lobsters/issues). * [Message me](https://lobste.rs/messages?to=pushcx) for administrative and moderator things. I don't see everything and I gotta sleep sometime. * E-mail my first name @malaprop.org regarding site security or if you can't log in to message me. If I've posted or commented about something here or in the chat room, I'd almost certainly love to talk more about it.
